post.title: What's one opinion you have that is unpopular with other libertarians?

body:
Well, it seems to have become unpopular recently at the very least. But I'm strongly in favor of open borders and free trade. The arguments I've seen thus far are broadly populist utilitarian. We live in the this country and thus should want wealth maximization locally as it benefits us (our tribe) and thus reduces welfare costs and improves the local populace.

My counter though is that I'm not a utilitarian, and I don't like welfare as it exists. I'd far rather see the people best qualified, and who want jobs the most to get them as it means the best people capable are being rewarded. This extends most recently to higher ed, in which I've not had many bernie bros say they support the move to limit foreign students because it's 'bad that foreigners take our grad student funding'. Anyone who has stepped foot on a college can tell you 2 things 1)american kids on average are there to party and 'discover themselves' and 2)foreign students will work harder at school and sacrifice more than you could imagine. Thus, fuck this idea of America first or American students first. If I wanted to see a bunch of spoiled children get tits up drunk and fuck until they figure out who they are I'd watch the newest shitty Netflix show. If I want to support the concept of higher education where the most motivated and intelligent students learn and extend fields I will welcome Asians or whoever else into the country, and Still be content knowing the fastest way to have people want to move to the US and become contributing tax payers is to have them recieve top level education and jobs here. Fuck the lazy people, from USA or otherwise.

post.title: What's one opinion you have that is unpopular with other libertarians?

body:
Well the idea that everyone should go to college is nonsense, many universities have whored themselves out and are nothing but degree mills that provide little in the way of actual education. 

The idea of completely free and open trade only works when everyone plays by the same set of rules but then you get countries like China which constantly game the system in their favor (and who can blame them) while the rest of the world has spent the last few decades trying to ignore it.

post.title: What's one opinion you have that is unpopular with other libertarians?

body:
I don't support open borders. In my opinion enforcing borders and immigration law is one of the few legitimate functions of the state. Without a border and without an official legal process to become a citizen, then how do you even have a country?

Maybe the immigration process in the US needs to be overhauled, but I don't think that we should just open up the border and invite everyone across freely.
body_html:
I don't support open borders. In my opinion enforcing borders and immigration law is one of the few legitimate functions of the state. Without a border and without an official legal process to become a citizen, then how do you even have a country?

Maybe the immigration process in the US needs to be overhauled, but I don't think that we should just open up the border and invite everyone across freely.

author.bio: An ugly giant bag of mostly water.
author.bio_html: An ugly giant bag of mostly water.

body:
Libertarianism as a movement was hijacked by the radical right in the 70s, shutting out most "moderate" libertarians and left-libertarians. This has been a bad thing for the movement as a whole.

Edit: I just realized this could be interpreted wrongly to imply that I'm against right-libertarians. Not at all. I just think that all libertarians (left, right, and center) should be presenting a united front against authoritarians until the biggest problem we have is debating whether or not local roads and fire departments should be privatized.
body_html:
Libertarianism as a movement was hijacked by the radical right in the 70s, shutting out most "moderate" libertarians and left-libertarians. This has been a bad thing for the movement as a whole.

I just think that all libertarians (left, right, and center) should be presenting a united front against authoritarians until the biggest problem we have is debating whether or not local roads and fire departments should be privatized.

parent.body:
I don't support open borders. In my opinion enforcing borders and immigration law is one of the few legitimate functions of the state. Without a border and without an official legal process to become a citizen, then how do you even have a country?

Maybe the immigration process in the US needs to be overhauled, but I don't think that we should just open up the border and invite everyone across freely.
parent.body_html:
I don't support open borders. In my opinion enforcing borders and immigration law is one of the few legitimate functions of the state. Without a border and without an official legal process to become a citizen, then how do you even have a country?

Maybe the immigration process in the US needs to be overhauled, but I don't think that we should just open up the border and invite everyone across freely.

body:
It's not the drawing of a picture that is the intellectual property. It's the trademark and uniqueness that the artist brought to the table.

A book with all the story and jibblets should be intellectual property, since it's a creation. A person has the right to defend such ideas and estate.

An inventor has the right to patent their invention. Same when someone discovers something like a cure for a disease.

Movies, comics, shows, they all need to have an owner or else anyone could barge in and ruin the legacy and it'll all be commie nonsense after that.

body:
That's not "defending" ideas, it's just an excuse for censorship. Theft would mean taking away someone's property, which doesn't happen in this case. What you've described is more like getting salty because someone saw something you had and decided to buy the same thing. By making that illegal, you are exerting control over what other people are allowed to do with their own property.

Also "ruining the legacy" is a moot point. It's very easy to see who produced something, so it's not like some random person can just change the canon if that's what you're thinking.

body:
It's not easy to see who produced something, actually. It's very hard and that's why we have to put a patent and copyright in order to sue those who wish to argue. An episode of the Simpsons did this perfectly already.

Your only argument here is that there might be an idea that is shared among people that *might* be copyrighted and that literally rarely happens and when it does people sue over it and usually win.

One idea that is a great example is the ability to have a mini game during a game's loading screen. It seems someone copyrighted it, making it so nobody else can have such a concept. That's something people could sue over, yet nobody has because it wasn't important and now we rarely have loading screens anyway.

That copyright helped in making games better by wanting to remove loading screens entirely instead of wanting to make them longer and simply entertain the player during such.

Also "ruining the legacy" is a moot point. It's very easy to see who produced something, so it's not like some random person can just change the canon if that's what you're thinking.

body:
That's just stupid. If it's not a big deal then why make it unlawful? And the loading screen example makes no sense, loading screens went away because games got faster and no longer needed them. It in fact made every game except the copyrighted one *worse* by not allowing it, plus it restricted what other people could do with their *own* game. Not to mention that even if it did make games "better", that's an argument for restricting individual rights in favor of the collective. The real thief here is the copyright holder and the government, as they are using it as an excuse to control others and their property. If they tell you what you can and can't make with your own materials, do you really own them, or do they? Do you own your own mind even? The concept of real property ownership is apparent and objective, but the ownsership of ideas is completely made up, as you cannot be robbed of them. If you don't want anyone using yours, don't divulge them.

It's censorship, plain and simple.

author.bio:

body:
I don't think you understand how ideas work. Say we turn such ideas physical. Let's say one thought is wood and another thought is metal, then we put them together and make a door. We sell that door. Why are we able to accept money from something we apparently didn't own?

Because it's the same thing as a real door being created and sold. Private production, just how capitalism wanted. Allowing the people to own ideas is communist. 

If you're cool with communism, that's fine, but understand that private ownership of ideas and inventions are capitalist.

The example did not show that every other game was worse. It showed that innovation causes the inevitable decay and removal of outdated ideas. This means that as time goes by, we protect the ones who created an idea and soon enough their idea becomes useless and the world moves onto the next one. 

We still need intellectual property in general. Even though we don't own the wood or the metal, exactly, we still aquire them and then create the door and we deserve the right to sell such a door, after putting in the labor, in accordance to what the market demands from said door.
